Good morning, everyone. We're going to follow the usual procedure of the presentations. We'll have questions from the floor then by phone and then through the web, and the event will last about an hour and a half. And it's going to be a long presentation, so we're going to start right away. And the Chairman of Iberdrola has the floor, Mr. Ignacio Galán.

Good morning, everyone. Thank you for your presence, both of you here and by phone and on the web. We'll follow the usual structure. First of all, I'll talk about the main highlights for the year, then the CFO will talk about the financial situation of the Group and subsequently, José Luis San Pedro will analyze the Spanish regulatory situation, which I think is of considerable interest, and I'll end with a brief summary and the questions.

In the general context with this debt crisis in the Eurozone, a reduction in demand in Europe, the operating profits of the Group was €7,650 million with a growth of 1.7% compared to last year. And it has been possible thanks to or in spite of a significant increase in levies that are more than €1.1 billion. And if we take away this effect, the operating profit would have grown 3.6%. The operating cash flow grew 5.8% to €6,047 million for the first time surpassing the €6 billion in one year.

From the operating point of view, we have continued to implement cost control measures and thereby improving efficiency. And in the financial area, intense activities have been carried out to optimize our balance sheet structure and to increase our financial solidity. As a result of this, financial expenses have been reduced 17.5% and the liquidity position is close to €9.3 billion with a leverage of 47.4% at the closing of 2011. In this way, in a general context, with the dropping credit ratings of all companies and countries, we have been able to maintain and ratify our A rating.

Finally, the recurring net profits increased 1.2% and net profits have reached €2,805 million. including the write offs amounting to €402 million. These results will enable us to maintain the remuneration to the shareholder at the same level as the previous year, a proposal that is going to be put to the next General Shareholders Meeting.

Moving on to the main aspects for the period, we can highlight that Iberdrola has increased the gross margin by 3.3% to €12,026 million, increasing by up to two-thirds the contribution of the regulated and renewable businesses that depend less on evolutions in demand.

The positive performance of the regulated business has made a decisive contribution, which represents close to 50% of the gross margin for the Group. The 6% growth obtained in this item reflects the impact of the improvements in the remuneration of the network business both in the U.S. and United Kingdom and the incremental contribution of Elektro in Brazil, which more than offsets the divestment in Connecticut Gas Companies.

Regarding renewables, in a very low market scenario in the U.S. and with the negative impact in the dollar and pound exchange rates, the gross margin grew 5% driven by the increase in wind power output thanks to which production has increased by 13%.

Regarding liberalized business, the gross margin has remained stable compared to 2010 affected by less margins in the UK and a 5.5% output production for the Group. The company has reacted to that difficult operating environment by focusing even more on cost efficiency. This has enabled us to control the growth in net operating cost below the gross margin, including the impact of the incorporation of Elektro in 2011. In this way, the efficiency ratio in terms of net operating expenses over gross margin have improved by 1.7%. The increase in this gross margin together with cost efficiency has made it possible to obtain this increase of 1.6% in EBITDA amounting to €7.65 billion.

By businesses, we can highlight first of all the good situation of the regulated activities driven by the increase in earnings and efficiency improvements. Secondly, the limited growth in the renewable business because of lower prices, especially as a result of the negative performance of exchange rates in the U.S. and UK. Excluding the effect of the sale of some assets made in 2010, the wind power EBITDA would have grown 4.3%.

And finally, the negative performance in the liberalized business, as I mentioned earlier, which is affected by the complex operating environment in the United Kingdom and the increase of more than 50% of the levies, which considerably raised to €621 million. This increase is especially significant in Spain, where this item has doubled in the last two years. And at the end of 2011, it amounts to €518 million. This is practically one-third of the EBITDA generated by the business in Spain. The main item in this levy is the nuclear production levy, which since 2006 is being paid by utility companies in Spain and currently represents €13 per megawatt hour, which is practically 25% of the turnover for this technology in Spain. And finally, we have to highlight the impact of the divestments in the Guatemala businesses and the effect that this has on the results of the liberalized business in Mexico.

Regarding the balance sheet management, the current environment has made us put our stakes on a prudent financial policy. This has enabled us to maintain a liquidity of almost €9.3 million, enough to cover the financial needs of the Group for the next two years, as well as improving the debt profile with an average maturity of 6.3 years. Also in February, this is important, we have refinanced 80% of the maturities expected for 2012.

As a result of all this, the Iberdrola financial ratios are still comfortably within the A rating ranges. The credit rating agencies, Moody's, Fitch and Standard & Poor's have reaffirmed the A rating level for Iberdrola and have improved their prospects to stable. And all of this in spite of having taken on organic investments amounting to €4 billion, 85% of which have been aimed at regulated and renewable businesses with the balance shared out in the various countries; to these investments we have to add the integration of Elektro and the merger with Iberdrola Renovables.

The solid performance of the company has enabled us to generate an operating cash flow, which for the first time as I said, exceeds €6 billion with a growth of 5.8% in the period. Net profits have reached €2.805 billion. The results obtained in the year together with the financial situation of the Group have enabled the Board to adopt a proposal for a shareholder remuneration for the year 2011 of at least €0.326 per share in line with the previous year. This proposal will be submitted to the next shareholders' meeting.

With this aim, the company will pay out a remuneration equivalent to the complementary dividend of at least €0.18 per share, €0.03 in cash according to the bylaws, a minimum of €0.15 through the new Flexible Dividend program. This remuneration is added to the €0.146 paid out in January. Regarding the regulatory aspects that the Managing Director José Luis San Pedro will discuss.

During 2011, there have been breakthroughs in all geographic areas, although there are still major challenges ahead. Starting with the UK, the first steps are being taken in the definition of a regulatory framework with the necessary predictability and stability to carry out the enormous investments that must be carried out both in networks and in new generation.

Regarding the Network business, I would like to highlight the efforts made by the regulator to guarantee a stability and an acceptable return for these activities. In this sense, last January 23, Ofgem officially announced that they have accepted the proposal from ScottishPower for the approval of tariffs for the energy transport business for the period 2013-2021. Investments are planned over £2.6 billion in the next eight years with acceptable certainty and profitability. And according to the regulator, this will provide good value to customers. With this new regulation for transport, the earnings of our Network business is defined in the UK since the distribution activity will continue to be enforced till 2015, within the current DPCR5 framework. And this is enabling us to carry out the investments of £2 billion in the period.

The UK generation activity, however, requires greater definition to establish a clear framework that can be assessed to provide incentives for the necessary investments since for environmental or obsolescence reasons the country must replace close to 40% of its generating facilities in the coming years. We, therefore, expect that the Electricity Market Reform will design this framework by the end of the first semester, both for traditional generation and for new renewable capacity as of 2017.

Finally, progress is being made to establish a cost allocation system for energy transport that will now penalize the generators further away from the consumer centers. This reform is key for the United Kingdom to be able to meet its objectives for the installation of new renewable power.

And moving on to the main regulatory landmarks in Spain that José Luis San Pedro will comment on later, the sector is characterized by a drop in electricity demand. At the end of 2011, the demand in Spain was similar to those of 2006. However, installed power was much higher than that year especially renewable power which has more than doubled in that period.

Also the firm stakes put on renewable technologies in Spain, that has gone much further than the objective laid down by the European Union of 20% for 2020, has made it possible for us to meet with that commitment for 2020. We have a very competitive traditional energy mix thanks to which, energy crisis on the Spanish market the so-called pool are 10% lower than the European average. Also the distribution networks in our country have a remuneration, which even after the recent increases is also around 10% lower than the average for the main European countries. However, the remuneration for renewables in Spain according to a study made by the European Council for Energy Regulators is higher than the European average, the repercussion per megawatt hour.

Not only that but the Spanish system is the European system with the highest cost. And this will be even more significant in the future in view of the development of the expensive and immature technologies that are taking place, especially solar energy. Additionally, the electric bill in Spain includes a number of costs such as a social bonus or incentives for national coal, which are superior to those in other countries in the European Union. These lead to a final supply price in Spain, which is slightly higher than the average.

In Spain, the so-called tariff deficit has been generated, which is the result of the difference between what companies are authorized to charge and what we are obliged to pay. This has been the direct consequence of the exponential growth experienced by premiums, especially the special regime in recent years, which has multiplied by three between 2007 and 2010 and is still growing significantly with an increase in the cost of the system and the premiums for solar and hybrid gas-solar systems or thermo solar systems. The growing volume in the deficit generated and the urgency in providing a sustainable solution have led the Spanish government to take measures to tackle the problem.

And we can highlight the recently approved Royal Decree 1/2012 to temporarily suspend the pre-allocation of procedures for the remuneration of economic incentives for new renewable and cogeneration facilities. Without a doubt, this is a positive measure with the proper objective that lays down the proper path and this is being developed by the Ministry for Industry, Energy and Tourism. This is an important measure but has a small impact in the short term and doesn't solve the problem since it doesn't prevent the errors already made with photovoltaic plants being repeated in the hybrid gas solar plants. On the other hand, we continue to move forward in the securitization of the tariff deficit, thanks to private issues, close to €13 billion have been securitized and around 7 billion are currently pending.
I'll now hand the floor over to José Sáinz Armada, so that he can explain the results for the year in greater detail.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. First, I would like to underline the most important aspects of the accounts and operating trends and I will finish with an analysis of the financial situation, the gross margin has grown 3.3% and now stands at €12 billion, although the exchange rate has subtracted nearly €144 million with growth in the regulated business in Spain and the UK and in the liberalized business in Spain and renewables that was to compensate the weak behavior of the liberalized business in the UK. And without the impact of the rate of exchange, the gross margin would have grown 4.5%. The consolidation of Elektro that provides €436 million compensates the loss of the assets sold in the United States, Guatemala and other assets that have also been sold that subtract nearly €300 million. The basic margin has gone up 3.2% in line with the gross margin and now stands at €12,275 million and the value of the emission rights allocated in 2011 is only €1 million higher than those allocated in 2010. Net operating expenses have grown 1.7% below the growth of the gross margin. And the lower expenses arising from the sale of the difference businesses, €103 million, have made it possible to compensate the greater costs of those associated to Elektro, €123 million and there has been increase in expenses in renewables as a consequence of the increase in capacity. And this fiscal year includes €443 million of non-recurrent impacts because of the hurricanes.

Net staff expenses have been reduced 3.6% and now stand at €1.6 billion. And even after the consolidation of Elektro due to certain non-recurrent effects that were included in the books in 2010, the total workforce has been increased by 1.7%. The net external services have grown 7% and now stands at €1.8 billion, fundamentally affected by the change of perimeter and because of the storm costs. The rate of exchange has improved operating expenses by €43 million. On the whole, the recurring net operating expenses have grown 4%. As regard to levies, there has been an increase of 29.9% and the figure is now €1.1 billion because of the increase of levies in the liberalized business in Spain, 31% more. And I will be talking about this later on and I will be talking about the increase in levies in the UK.

The consolidated EBITDA has grown 1.6% thanks to a growth of 3.3% of the basic margin and because of an operating expense that goes up less. However, the strong increase in levies, nearly 22%, has penalized the evolution of EBITDA. The consolidation of Elektro makes it possible to compensate the sale of assets and the negative impact in the evolution of the rate of exchange and the homogenization of the EBITDA in the regulated business in Spain where in the last quarter, we updated the remuneration of that year and of 2009 totaling €75 million which is what we had for 2009.

Therefore, the recurrent pro forma of the Group had grown 1.7%, which is very similar to the figure that was reported. The growth of EBITDA is based on our diversified business model where the most stable and less risky business like the regulated business and renewables provide 71% of the EBITDA and this compensates the greater probability of the liberalized business.

And talking about the operating profits per businesses, and starting off with the regulated business, the EBITDA that includes Spain, UK, United States and Brazil with Elektro has grown 5.5% and now stands at €3,825 million, which means that there's a 4.5% improvement in terms of the gross margins. And in like-for-like terms, all of the business areas provide growth at a recurrent level and this has been boosted by the regulatory agreements and by the synergies that arise from implementing efficiency standards. The regulated business in Spain provides 41% of the EBITDA, in the UK 22%; in the United States, 14% and Brazil 23% after consolidating Elektro.

The EBITDA of the regulated business in Spain has dropped 0.2% and now stands at a figure of €2,555 million although in like for like terms it rose 4.8%. We have to remember that new regulatory framework is homogenous since the fourth quarter of 2010 and the drop of 1.4% in the gross margin is due to the fact that the improvement of 6.1% in income for the regulated business is not sufficient to counteract the negative impact in the inter-annual comparative analysis totaling €75 million.

On the other hand, the positive evolution of net operating expenses that have dropped 6.4% thanks to improvements in efficiency have made it possible for EBITDA to only [drop] 4.2%. The regulated business in the UK has reached an EBITDA of €832 million with a growth of 4.2% because of the increase of 4.4% in the gross margin as a consequence of the increase in the income due to the investments and due to the remuneration of the DPCR5 business, which was applied as from April 1, 2010 and operating expenses have been reduced by 1.7%.

The impact related to the rate of exchange change has been negative. So that means that the EBITDA would have improved 5.4%. The regulated business in the United States provides an EBITDA of €548 million under the IFRS regulations, which means that it's a 23% slump. As regards to the negative effect of the sale of the gas business in Connecticut, which means €94 million less in EBITDA, there's been a nonrecurring impact of €43 million because of hurricanes and storms, which has to do with one of adjustments which linked to the negative effect of the rate of exchange, €27 million represents most of the slump.

However, the underlying evolution is positive and it means that it's €32 million more in EBITDA, which arises from an improvement in the operating aspects of the business in spite of the bad fourth quarter and the increase in tariffs because of the new rate case in the main line have made it possible to make the EBITDA grow nearly by 4% and the EBITDA in Brazil has grown 60% and now stands at €890 million after incorporating Elektro to the consolidation perimeter, which since May 1 has provided €312 million and then there is 2.6% growth in electrical demand and new hydraulic (sic) hydroelectric facilities that have been commissioned, which also have produced growth. And the gross margin of the business has grown 66.1% and €486 million has to do with incorporation of Elektro. The operating expenses have gone up 85.7% or €151 million, of which €123 million has to do with this incorporation and the rest has to do with inflation and greater activity. And EBITDA without Elektro would have grown 3.8%.

And now I would like to move on to the operating profits of the liberalized business that includes Spain, the UK and Mexico. EBITDA has dropped 7.4% and now stands at €2.2 billion whereas the EBITDA in Spain has gone up 5.9% thanks to an improvement in margins and because of a limitation in net operating expenses in the UK, there has been a 40.8% slump because of lower margins and less sales and less production that was down in Mexico 11% because they have been affected by the sale of the Guatemala business and the devaluation of the dollar.

Net operating expenses reduced 2.7% whereas the levies have undergone a very strong increase 50.7% that really penalizes the EBITDA of the business. And starting off with the liberalized business in Spain it has to be mentioned that there has been a reduction in the production of the ordinary regime of 13% because of the slump of 22% in hydraulic (sic) hydroelectric production and 7% in nuclear power, this is one of the driest winters we've had in the last 50 years. Even so the hydraulic (sic) hydroelectric reserves were 51% till December the 31st which is slightly above the historic figure and the average sale price is €61 per megawatt hour which has given us a greater margin although the procurement cost environment has been growing and the basic margin has grown 6.4%, which linked to the limitation of operating expenses which have dropped 4.6% because of cost limitations and some other specific effects of 2010, this has allowed us to counteract the strong increase in the levies paid, 30.5% more, which now represents 33% of the business's EBITDA. And the growth of this item is 5.9% and now has reached €1.5 billion. There's also a positive effect of €102 million related to resettlements. And for 2012, there are 56 terawatts hour of production already sold at a price in excess of €60 megawatt hour.

As we've pointed out in the previous transparency, the EBITDA of the Spanish liberalized business is affected by the increase in levies. In fact, in the last two years levies in this business have been multiplied by 2.4 since €216 million in 2009 up to €518 million in 2011, which represents an impact of €300 million in two years and this means that the profitability relative to the invested capital in the in the Generation business, especially nuclear power stations is below the cost of capital.

Until 2006, practically no nuclear levies were paid and now they account for nearly €200 million. According to our calculations, the total of levies in terms of nuclear production represent an average of €13 per megawatt hour, which is in line with the rates applied in Germany and Belgium. And the levies paid to the states represent €339 million, apart from those that are specifically nuclear, there are €150 million more that are linked to energy efficiency programs and to the social bonus and the rest of the local and regional levies total €179 million. We have the eco levy of Extremadura although we have filed an appeal before the Court of Justice and the High Court of Justice in Spain.

The basic margin of the liberalized business in the UK presents a slump of 11% in which there's been a decline in sales, 5% in electricity, 19% in gas, and very low spreads with higher procurement costs that have not been compensated by an equivalent increase in the price of sale of electricity and a 22% reduction because of the lower spreads in the market.

Net operating expenses have grown 4.1% due to non-recurrent effects that affected the annual comparative. There's been a reclassification of the CERT and CESP levies that are imposed by the regulator for energy efficiency programs based on the net operating expenses and therefore there's been a very significant increase but this has been compensated because in the net operating expenses there was a positive item of €50 million in terms of insurance indemnities in 2010. So that means that the EBITDA presents a slump of 41% and now stands at €322 million.

However and as we pointed out in Q3, as from August, there was an improvement in the evolution of the businesses especially in the area of gas, with increases in the unitary margin arising from an increase in tariffs. And this improvement has been consolidated in the fourth quarter with a recovery of margins in gas and electricity. So that means that the results of this area will improve in 2012 because of an increase in margins. And as regards the liberalized business in Mexico, there's been a slump of 11% in the EBITDA and it now stands at €362 million and the effect produced by the rate of exchange has subtracted €18.4 million and this has had a negative impact on the business in Guatemala that has reduced the EBITDA by €58 million and that being said the underlying evolution of EBITDA has improved 1.5%.

And as regards the EBITDA of the Renewables business, we're talking about €1.5 billion because of greater costs because of an increase in capability and because of the contracts and the maintenance contracts that have come to an end and because of the merger costs and because of lower prices that is €66.3 million below the figure reported for 2010 because of the greater weight of the business in the United States versus Spain. Where in the case of Hydraulic business, the load factor in the fourth quarter was bad and the evolution of the rate of exchange has had a negative impact of €26 million.

The pure wind power EBITDA has grown 4.3%. Operating capacity has grown 10% and now stands at €13.2 million (sic) [13.2 MW] and the installed capacity has increased 9.2%. The average load factor now stands at 25.7%, which is slightly below 25.8% reported one year ago. Although in Q4, it was 0.4 points lower and as I mentioned this was affected by the low level of wind power produced in Spain and EBITDA has dropped 6.7% because of the increase in provisions that have grown 187% and now stand at €528 million. And this increase has no impact on the cash flow especially because of the €332 million produced by impairment of assets that are as follows.

Firstly, €286 million in thermal assets in the UK due to the cancellation of the CCS project and the carbon flow that was announced by the British Energy Authorities that reduces the expectations in terms of spreads and the life of these assets. And secondly, €46 million related to promotional costs of the wind parks in the United States where considered on the current situation, they're not going to be developed. And then we've also extended the life of wind farms from 20 to 25 years which reduces the payback by €66 million. Although, amortizations have grown 4.1% because of the increase in investments made in the Regulated business as well as in the Renewables business.

And the financial results have improved 17.5% thanks, among other things, to the impact produced by the hedging for rates of exchange for these subsidiaries, which represent €87 million. And another important impact comes from changed provisions related to the deficit totaling €85 million. Financial expenses associated to the debt has grown 5% because of the increase of 40 points in the cost of the interest paid and now stands at 4.6% including the new debt in reals that Elektro has provided and the fact that it is partially compensated by a 3% reduction of the average figure of the debt. On the other hand the greater levels of remuneration of the deficit has a positive effect of €31 million because this is a remuneration system that's linked to the Euribor of three months of the previous year which in 2010 was 0.7 and in 2011 it was 1.05 and to finish with the analysis of the results I have to point that the net recurrent profits have grown 1.2% and now stand at €2.6 billion. However, the reported net profits have dropped 2.3% as the President pointed out.

Firstly – the difference between both items is due to the following, firstly because of the impairment of assets totaling €402 million gross because in the case of the €286 million related to thermal assets in the UK and €46 million for renewables, we have to add another €70 million as regards the participation of Gamesa, which can be seen here in the consolidation by the equity method where we postponed the dates of achievement of these objectives because of the weakness of the wind power market.

And secondly because they were €133 million less in 2010 in the case of extraordinary results and both effects are partially compensated by lower tax levels and because of a levy that is two points lower in the UK that means that we're paying less deferred taxes than in 2010 totaling €83 million. And also because there's been a change in the taxation policy in the Unites States totaling €169 million after reaching an agreement with the tax authority on lawsuits prior to the acquisition of ScottishPower. And the effective tax rate in 2011 was 15.7%, vis-à-vis 23.6% in 2010.

Moving on to a quick analysis of the Group's financial situation, during 2011 there was a reduction in the tariff deficit pending collection of €2.257 billion going from €5.248 billion at the end of 2010 to €2.991 billion at the end of 2011. 11 further issues have been made between private and public issues amounting to close to €10 billion, of which €2,961 million correspond to Iberdrola.

Also the new government has continued with the policy of securitizing the deficit and in the two first months of the year, 10 new further issues have been made through private placements amounting to €2.4 billion, of which €732 million correspond to Iberdrola, which improves even further our comfortable financial position.

In recent days, it seems that there have been new operations and this would mean that we would receive around €1 billion in the first months of 2012. In 2011, Iberdrola had €1,141 million in new deficit, which represents approximately €4.50 billion overall for the system and it has collected €437 million in the usual settlements through the tariff.

The company has continued with its policy to strengthen the balance sheet in 2011. Net debt grew slightly to €31,706 million because of the acquisition of Elektro and the purchasing of the minority shares of Iberdrola Renovables partially offset by Qatar and the Group's cash flow generation. Leverage reached 48.8% including deficit of 46.4% excluding it.

The balance sheet strengthening policy and the growth achieved in operating cash flow generation make it possible for the company to increase the strength of its financial ratios including the tariff deficit in such a way that ratios have stayed at the levels that the agencies required for the rating A- to A3. It must be highlighted that Moody's after the recent drop in the Kingdom of Spain has maintained our rating and stable prospects.

The ratio with respect to net debt is 21.4% if we include the tariff deficit pending collection. The ratio is 19.5% versus 19.1% last year. The ratio of retained cash flow over net debt is 18.9%. If we include the tariff deficit pending collection, the ratio improves to 17.2% from 16.7% in 2010. And we can also highlight our excellent liquidity position. We currently have €9.294 billion in liquidity and available credit lines. Of the total, less than €2 billion mature before 2014. Therefore, we have a strong liquidity position that enabled us to cover 24 months of financial needs. Especially if we compare it with the debts maturity profiles, where in 2012 we only have €1.880 billion and €2.778 billion in 2013, there's no excessive concentration of maturities in any year and the forecast is suitable for a company with the financial strength of Iberdrola. The average life of debt has gone to 6.3 years from 6.2 years, and now José Luis San Pedro will comment on the regulation issues.

Good morning, everyone. If anyone thinks that I'm going to give a solution to the sector now, I'm afraid I'm going to disappoint you. My aim is to give some objective figures that will enable us to do two things. Use figures to assess many of the proposals that are being made to solve the situation in the sector but there's no real information base for them. And secondly, try to focus the problem because until we know and examine the problem, it's going to be difficult to find a solution.

Firstly, I'm going to define the tariff deficit. As we know it, which is the difference between the earnings recognized in the sector through its activities and the payments that the regulator obliges the consumers to pay. And since it doesn't coincide, there's a negative difference or against this which is what we call the tariff deficit.

This tariff deficit has been financed through a Royal Decree by five companies. In fact, three companies financed 90% of the deficit with a financial cost, which is the Euribor minus spreads, and which we accept because we were told that this was a temporary one-year financing, and therefore, with a really low cost. The fact is that these have been multi-annual financing. We haven't collected 2006 yet and we still have financial costs without a spread. So we are evaluating what the financial costs are that haven't been recognized and they amount to more than €1 billion.

This problem, which initially had a dimension that could be taken on, has grown exponentially as of 2008, with the coming into operation of what we call the photovoltaic bubble. At this point, the deficit pending securitization, I think Pepe Sainz mentioned it, for the sector is around €7 billion. Including in the €7 billion, the ex-anti and ex-post deficit for 2011 and the ex-anti deficit for 2012.

The history of the deficit has changed over the years. When it started in the year 2000 I think it was because of volatility in electricity output in Spain, which was very much affected by the price of fuels and the hydroelectric resources led to volatility in generation costs. And the generator wanted to flattened those costs by saying I'll drop them when the actual cost is low and I'll increase them in the opposite situation so I won't pass on this volatility to the consumer. This initially was a good idea but as of 2005, as we can see on the chart, it became a structural issue. And instead of flattening the volatility in generation costs, it hid the actual environmental cost that the sector was incurring and it has become a structural deficit that amounts to around €5 billion.

So we can now start to define the problem. We have the problem that we need to reduce the annual cost of supply by around €5 billion and we have to find a solution to an accumulated debt of around €24 billion.

And let's see what we can analyze to solve the problem. This chart shows what all electric energy consumers have paid in 2010, €37 billion and where this money has gone. Well, 20% of that money has gone to the inland revenue, VAT, and the electricity levy. 30% has gone to pay the regulatory decisions that have been made, that have nothing to do with supply and that have been made by the regulator over the years. That's 30% of the cost for the sector and in 2010 amounts to €11 billion. And on the left, we have the conventional costs. In other words, the production costs at market price and it includes all the output of renewable energy at market price. And the second blue square, the costs of the transport and distribution in Spain, which amount to €6.9 billion.

And two very clear messages here, if I take away the left side of the chart, the sector continues to provide energy with the same guarantee of supply and at a price that is half the price the consumer is currently paying. Secondly, the associated costs decided by the regulator amount to the same as the total production costs and they are almost double the transport and conventional distribution costs. And I think that this chart gives us various clues on where the solution to the problem may lie.

Regarding the associated costs, which as you will remember represented €11 billion, part of it are the premiums for the special regime and another part, which are various costs and decisions made by the regulator. The first is not having transferred to the tariff the total supply costs. This has generated a deficit, a debt that has had to be paid. Therefore, the first part of this associated costs are the annuities that have to be paid for the tariff deficit from previous years.

There's an added cost because of the extra peninsular compensation and by law, this ought to be included in the national budget. There's an energy savings and efficiency plan that I don't know why has to be funded by the Spanish generators. And there's an interruptibility service or a cut-off service that is paid at a price that is 10 times higher than the price paid by conventional generators. And there's an added cost for domestic coal to guarantee the purchasing of around 29 million tons per year. All these decisions that have nothing to do with the cost of supply represent €3.299 billion.

And now we're going to slowly analyze whether the problem lies in generation earnings or somewhere else. This curve on the right shows the evolution since 2003 of the average monthly prices of the Spanish spot market and the average monthly prices of the European spot prices. And we can see that both lines practically run in parallel and this is logical because the power stations that establish the marginal cost are the same and they have the same price.

But even though the curves are very close together, I would like to highlight that in these eight years the average price in Spain of the spot market has been €4 lower than the average European price and when I say €4, and I multiply it by the output which is close to 300 terawatts per year. This means that the Spanish consumer has paid for energy €1.2 billion less than the European consumer just on the energy side.
